title: Intro
description: Hi, I'm Paul Doherty, a recent Computing Science graduate from Glasgow, Scotland. This website covers a variety of the projects I have worked on over the past years, from software development to entirely creative projects. Scroll through the wheel on the left to get a preview of each project and click into an item to read a detailed description.

content.value: My name is Paul Doherty and I am a recent Computing Science graduate from the University of Glasgow. My absolute favourite thing to do in life is to create unique experiences for others to enjoy. The best way I have found to do this is to combine my computing and software design skills with my creative side to put together big projects. This can come in a variety of forms such as hosting live online/in person events, creating content, or even developing games.

I find that game design is one of the most effective ways to utilise my skills. It combines almost every art form you can think of into one massive project. Many of these are forms I enjoy working in. I have been drawing my whole life and now find myself creating concept art for my games before developing these ideas. Creating art for sprites and textures is extremely rewarding when you see these appear in your game. 3D modelling and animation is something I picked up later that was very tough initially, but paid off massively once I got the hang of it. This made me much more comfortable venturing into developing 3D games. Designing levels and gameplay features requires me to think extremely creatively. There are so many amazing ideas out there that when you come up with something that feels truly unique, it is very special.

This site acts as a showcase of some of the projects I have worked on over the past years. Most of these projects involve some sort of software/computing aspect, but a few others take a more creative focus. I aim for this to exemplify my ability across many different fields and to be a platform for me to show off what I am passionate about and proud of being involved in.

The logo which appears on the left of the screen was a logo I created in 2017, when I was 15. It was originally intended as a logo for my YouTube channel but has evolved into a symbol I like to use to represent myself. It is a dragon in the shape of an 'S,' standing for my gamertag back in the day.

title: AR Flatpack Assembly
description: The project for my final year dissertation at university. This is a tool to help users assemble flatpack furniture without paper instructions using augmented reality on the Microsoft Hololens 2.

content.value: As my final year dissertation project for university, I designed and developed an augmented reality (AR) application, built on the Microsoft Hololens 2, which aimed to assist users in assembling flatpack furniture. The aim of the project was to determine the benefits of hands-free AR instructions over a traditional set of paper instructions.

To gain a background, a comprehensive literature review was carried out. This studied previous AR applications in industrial and consumer contexts. A gap was discovered for consumers where industries had taken advantage of AR capabilites.AR had been proven effective at providing instructions for workers in an indrustrial environment, yet this hadn't been experimented much with in a more general context.

An application was designed which would use the composite design pattern to translate steps to assemble a piece of furniture into an AR format. Two methods were created to demonstrate an instruction in AR: 
The first was by tracking real life objects using accurate 3D models and highlighting the location it should be placed while also informing the user if it had been placed correctly. This method would take advantage of
VisionLib

object tracking. 
The second method was more simple. It animated a 3D model of the current part from one location to another, indicating the correct way to place a part. 

This application was developed in Unity and built to the Hololens. Individual and accurate 3D models of every part of a piece of furniture had to be modelled using Blender. These were then set up as furniture parts in Unity which were ordered in the order they should be added within a piece of furniture. Each part came under a component and a component could either be a part of the furniture or the entire furniture itself. This meant that separate parts could be put together before being added to the furniture. For example, a drawer could be assembled by itself before being added to a bedside table. 

A few of the features relied on the VisionLib SDK. Parts could be tracked between real life and digital space as long as the camera could recognise an inital pose for the object. This was tricky to get right in context as the application was often used in cluttered spaces which led to the application struggling to keep track of parts. VisionLib also came with an inbuilt voice command feature. This meant that all user interaction with the application was done through voice. 

Some  pilot testing was carried out which concluded that the application needed some user experience improvements. Some features that were added to maximise the user friendliness were a view part command which gave users a close up, rotating view of the current part and an arrow that pointed to the current part when it exited the field of view.

A user study was carried out which split participants into 3 groups: paper, tracking, and animation. Each group assembled a bedside table using their given instructions. Any time a participant encountered an issue, it was noted and categorised. This was used to measure the effectiveness of each set of instructions. 

AR proved to be effective over paper instructions, especially the animated instructions. Participants tended to select the wrong parts and place parts wrong more while reading off paper whereas AR helped them to be more sure of what a part looked like and exactly how it should be placed. The object tracking method did not get used in its intended way very often as the tracking was just too unreliable.Otherwise, the biggest issue with the AR instructions was the learning curve. Users made most of their mistakes near the start of the process but towards the end, made significanly less. 

The project concluded that AR has some serious potential in improving the experience of assembling flatpack furniture. The lack of availability of hands-free AR currently is holding this back. An application which had improved object tracking a clear user guide to mitigate the learning curve would make for an excellent product.

title: Charity Football Match
description: Hosted a charity football match in memory of a close friend. Raised money and donations for a local foodbank. Gathered a live crowd but also developed a program to enhance a live broadcast/replay of the event.

content.value: In early 2024 I lost a very close friend. In order to pay tribute to him, my friends and I set up a charity elevens football match in his name. Together we gathered a crowd, raised £4,910, and collected food donations for the local foodbank.

There was a group of four of us that were involved with planning this event. Plans started small but quickly expanded over time as we realised we were capable of more. We had to organise a range of factors including but not limited to the following:

As a group we split all of the issues between us and came together every week to discuss progress and help each other out. We created posters and advertised everywhere we could. We reached out to members of the local community which led to us getting a
story in the news
, and helped us get a fantastic venue.

For those that couldn't make the day, we decided to record the event. I wanted the footage to appear as close to a regular football broadcast as possible. To do this I developed a program which could track the match and display match info on the recording. This program was built with Python and connected with OBS to put graphics on the screen. 

It was a priority of mine to keep the application from being too specific to this one game. This meant that I wanted to be able to set up and broadcast any possible football match. To achieve this I set up a system of 'Games', 'Teams' and 'Players'. This allows the user to set up whatever football matches possible by creating custom teams with custom players. A saving system was set up for each of these objects which means that users could even save a match in its exact state midway through.
An editor was developed to allow a user-friendly way to customise teams and players. All information of a team could be edited and the players on a team can be managed.

The editor also came with a formation manager which could be used to set up any possible formation with the players off the bench. Positions could be swapped by dragging and dropping players and the overall formation could be changed by typing a valid formation in the text box. The formation was used at the start of a match broadcast to present the starting eleven.

content.alt: The formation as shown in broadcast

content.value: Once a match was set up, the software connected with OBS using web sockets. A user interface with match controls would then appear. This panel allows the operator to start and stop each half, add goals, cards, substitutions, replays and more. It was a priority that the operator had all the required information present in a clear way while also having as much control as possible to ensure it could be operated live with minimal errors. In the case that errors were made, delete buttons were added. The interface also included replay controls. At certain points such as goals being scored, the footage will be split and the program will automatically go to the end of that clip to show a replay of what happened.

The match footage had a display over it to communicate facts of the game. It could show substitutions, cards and goals. All of the display features had animations tied to them which were all manually implemented by moving objects or updating a mask iteratively within a loop. A penalty shootout feature was even implemented for the case of a draw, but this feature was never required.

content.alt: The display at the start of a half

content.value: This application was fully capable of broadcasting the match live online. Unfortunately I did not have access to the required tech to connect multiple cameras to one device  and I could not guarantee a reliable internet connection. This meant that the footage was recorded with one camera angle and uploaded later. It is a goal of mine to have the match go out live in the likely event that we have another charity match next year.

I personally designed the badges and kits for both teams. The teams were based on two of our friend's favourite places, Malone's Irish Bar in Glasgow and the home ground of Arthurlie FC, Dunterlie. 

 AC Malones:
Dunterlie Dynamos:

title: UI Strategy Game
description: Developed as part of a team project, this user interface focused game simulates an economy and allows you to enact policies and balance your budget to get the best results. Requirements for project were set by a customer.

title: Racing Game Prototype
description: The beginnings of a dream project. A Unity prototype with custom vehicles and vehicle scripts. Includes a tool for designing roads and tracks using nodes and bezier curves. Plans for a larger game being established through concept art and feature designs.

title: This Portfolio
description: This portfolio was developed using React. While it wasn't my first attempt at web development, it was my first time using React and attempting such a unique design for a website. The website is inspired by 2000s video game and console user interfaces.

title: Creative Work
description: A showcase of some of my artwork and creative projects.

content.value: This is my Minecraft world which I started in 2015. This began when I developed an interest in skyscrapers as a young teen which has eventually developed into a love of city planning and world building. I have worked on this over the years since, eventually coming to build 4 unique cities. The world is filled with details, lore, and easter eggs.
This is a very new project but one that has been on my mind for a long time. It is a tropical pirate haven named Chillis Island, which is also the location in
RAaEzo Man Battle.
Planet Coaster 2 is the perfect tool to build this world in with it's 3D building and terraforming capabilities.

A range of my creations in Cities Skylines 2. I enjoy creating custom maps that others can use themselves. My best custom map was a scaled down version of Glasgow and the West coast of Scotland created from scratch. This map received over 1000 downloads on
Paradox Mods.
I was incredibly proud of the racetrack and football stadium I built on one of my cities. These venues saw the praise of a prominent and very skilled member of the Cities Skylines community.
